context:
Program Name: Supply Chain Management
Code: B429
Credential: Ontario College Graduate Certificate
Duration: 2 semesters
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $6,642.00
International Tuition: $18,253.00
Location: St. James Campus

Courses are delivered with an emphasis on applied and experiential learning, covering topics such as supply chain optimization, risk management, and sustainable sourcing.
Industries: transportation, pharmaceutical, oil and gas, retail
Skills gained: technical expertise, innovative thinking, relationship-building.

context:
Program Name: Supply Chain Management
Code: B429
Credential: Ontario College Graduate Certificate
Duration: 2 semesters
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $6,642.00
International Tuition: $18,253.00
Location: St. James Campus
Program Overview: A one-year program that teaches students how to design and manage supply chains in various industries. Prepares students for positions in global sourcing and procurement management, transportation and distribution management, production management, business planning, supply chain analysis, and logistics management.
Courses are delivered with an emphasis on applied and experiential learning, covering topics such as supply chain optimization, risk management, and sustainable sourcing.
Industries: transportation, pharmaceutical, oil and gas, retail
Skills gained: technical expertise, innovative thinking, relationship-building.

The Supply Chain Management program at the college equips graduates with skills to guide decision-making based on strategic objectives, stakeholder expectations, and supply chain functions. Graduates can enter various positions in global sourcing and procurement management, transportation and distribution management, production management, business planning, supply chain analysis, and logistics management. Common job titles include: supply chain planning coordinator, operations/logistics coordinator, operations systems analyst, inventory analyst, business demand coordinator, and sales analyst.

To graduate, students must complete 13 mandatory courses over two semesters. Semester 1 includes the following courses with no prerequisites: MGMT 4092 - Supply Chain Strategy, MGMT 4093 - Supply Chain Sustainability, MGMT 4094 - Sourcing and Purchasing, MGMT 4095 - Risk Management, MGMT 4096 - Technology Integration and Analysis, MARK 4005 - Applied Business Communication, and MGMT 4097 - Career Planning.

Semester 2 courses and their prerequisites are: MGMT 4098 - Performance Management and Logistics (MGMT 4092), MGMT 4099 - Transportation and Logistics (MGMT 4092), MGMT 4100 - Warehousing (MGMT 4092), MGMT 4101 - Supply Chain Management Design and Optimization (MGMT 4092 & MGMT 4093), MGMT 4102 - Inventory and Forecasting (MGMT 4096), and MGMT 4103 - Experiential Learning.

Program learning outcomes include the ability to examine the connections between strategic objectives, stakeholder expectations, and supply chain design, functions, processes, and roles to guide decision-making, problem-solving, and coordination of tasks.

The text mentions that the role of a supply chain management professional includes determining the value added and financial implications of supply chain decisions, ensuring compliance with legal and regulatory obligations, using risk mitigation tools, contributing to strategic planning and scheduling, coordinating efficient handling and movement of goods, services, materials and related information, identifying and managing continuous improvements, using technologies to enhance performance, monitoring trends and emerging technologies, and establishing strategic relationships with stakeholders. The text provides information about various aspects of applying to George Brown College, including financial assistance eligibility for OSAP, admission requirements (Ontario College diploma, Ontario College advanced diploma, bachelor's degree or equivalent), English language proficiency requirements and testing, course exemptions, instructions on how to apply (domestic and international students), contact information for domestic and international student admissions, and financial aid inquiries. However, no specific program name or information is mentioned in the text.

Therefore, the extracted information is as follows:

- Financial Assistance: Approved for OSAP funding if applicant meets eligibility criteria
- Admission Requirements: Ontario College diploma (2-year), Ontario College advanced diploma (3-year), bachelor's degree or equivalent
- English Language Proficiency: Required for international students without English proficiency test results and those considered based on work experience
- Course Exemptions: College and university credits may qualify for exemptions; visit transfer guide for more information
- How to Apply: Domestic students apply through Ontario Colleges, international students apply through George Brown College Online Application System
- Contact Us: Information sessions held regularly; contact admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit Admissions section for domestic inquiries, and book a virtual meeting or submit an inquiry for international contacts; financial aid inquiries can be made to FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit Financial Aid section.

The text provides information on how to contact different departments at George Brown College for inquiries related to financial aid, program advising, specific programs (in this case, Supply Chain Management), and international recruitment. Here's the extracted factual information:

- Financial Aid: FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid section.
- Entry Advising: Make an appointment to see an Entry Advisor. Review frequently asked questions.
- Centre for Business: business@georgebrown.ca, (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160. Contact Sam Lampropoulos, Program Co-ordinator for Supply Chain Management at slamprop@georgebrown.ca. Follow on Instagram and LinkedIn.
- International Recruitment: Book a virtual meeting or submit an inquiry through the International Contact Us page.
- Campus Location: Offered out of the School of Management, classes usually take place at St. James Campus, mainly at 200 King St. E. and 290 Adelaide St. E., Toronto, ON, Canada. Campus tours are offered regularly. Check out the virtual tour.
- Contact Information: Provide your first name, last name, email, and indicate whether you're domestic or international along with your country of origin to sign up for tailored resources and learn more about George Brown College.
